translated: In the same way, Kāśyapa, the bodhisattva who has first given rise to the mind of awakening gathers the medicine of generosity, all of which he gathers without discrimination, with an equal mind towards all beings,

original: cikitsā prayati /
analyzed: cikitsā prayati
translated: and strives for healing.

original: tatredamucyate
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Here it is said:

original: himavanta ye paravatarāja bheṣajā rohanti te nirmamanirvikalpā /
analyzed: ye bheṣajāḥ rohanti te nirmama nirvikalpā
translated: The herbs that grow on the snowy king of mountains, free from mine and discrimination,

original: yatropanāmyanti ca taṃ śamenti vyādhiṃ jarā cāpanayanti kecit
analyzed: yatra upanāmyanti ca tam śamā inti vyādhim jarā ca apanayanti kecid
translated: are brought forth and pacify that disease, and some remove old age.

original: jinātmajāpi samudānayanti yaṃ jñānabhaiṣajya vikalpa muktvā /
analyzed: samudānayanti yam muktvā
translated: The offspring of the Victorious Ones also gather that medicine of wisdom, free from discrimination,

original: hitārtha sarvaṃ samudānayanti samacitta sattveṣu cikitsa kurvan //
analyzed: hita artha sarvam samudānayanti samacitta sattveṣu cikitsa kurvan
translated: and gather everything for the benefit of all, with an impartial mind, practicing healing towards beings.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa navacandro namaskṛyate sā pūrṇacandro na tathā namaskṛyate /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa nava candraḥ namaskṛyate sā pūrṇa candraḥ na tathā namaskṛyate
translated: Just as, O Kāśyapa, the new moon is worshipped, but not so much the full moon,

original: evameva kāśyapa ye mama śraddadhanti te balavantataraṃ bodhisattvaṃ namaskartavya /
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa ye mama śraddadhanti te balavantataram bodhisattvam namaskartavya
translated: in the same way, O Kāśyapa, those who have faith in me should pay homage to the powerful Bodhisattva,

original: na tathāgata tatkasya heto bodhisattvanirjātā hi tathāgatāḥ tatredamucyate
analyzed: na tathāgata tat kasya hetoḥ bodhisattva nirjātāḥ hi tathāgatāḥ tatra idam ucyate
translated: not so much to the Tathāgata. Why is that? Because the Tathāgatas are born from the Bodhisattvas. About this, the following is said:

original: candraṃ navaṃ sarva namaskaronti tameva pūrṇaṃ na namaskaronti /
analyzed: candram navam namaskaronti tam eva pūrṇam na namaskaronti
translated: All worship the new moon, but not so much the full moon.

original: imeva yaḥ śraddadhatai jinātmajo sa bodhisattvaṃ namatā jinā na tu / //
analyzed: sa bodhisattvam namatā jināḥ na tu
translated: Those who have faith in the Victorious Ones should pay homage to the Bodhisattva, the offspring of the Victorious Ones, not so much to the Victorious Ones.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa mātrikā sarvaśāstragrahaṇajñāne pūrvaṅgamā /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa mātrikā sarva śāstra grahaṇa jñāne pūrvaṅgamā
translated: Just as, O Kāśyapa, the mātrkā is the forerunner in the knowledge of grasping all treatises,

original: evameva kāśyapa prathamacittotpādiko bodhisattvaḥ sarvabuddhavikurvitādhiṣṭhāne 'nuttare pūrvaṅgamaḥ //
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa prathama citta utpādikaḥ bodhisattvaḥ sarva buddha vikurvita adhiṣṭhāne nuttare pūrvaṅgamaḥ
translated: in the same way, O Kāśyapa, the bodhisattva who has first given rise to the mind is the forerunner in all the miracles and blessings of the Buddhas.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa na jātu kenaciccandramaṇḍalam utsṛjya tārakarūpaṃ namaskṛta pūrvaṃ /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa na jātu kenacid candra maṇḍalam utsṛjya tāraka rūpam namaskṛta pūrvam
translated: Just as, O Kāśyapa, the orb of the moon has never before been worshipped by anyone, having abandoned the form of the stars,

original: evameva kāśyapa na jātu paṇḍito mama śikṣāpratipanna bodhisattvaṃ riñcitvā śrāvakaṃ namaskaroti /
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa na jātu paṇḍitaḥ mama śikṣā pratipanna bodhisattvam riñcitvā śrāvakam namaskaroti
translated: in the same way, O Kāśyapa, a wise person, having abandoned a śrāvaka, never worships a bodhisattva who is engaged in my training.

original: tatredamucyate
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: na kenaci candra vivarjayi tvā namaskṛtā tāragaṇā kadācit /
analyzed: na kenacid candra tvā namaskṛtā tāra gaṇā kadācid
translated: No one has ever worshipped the multitude of stars, having abandoned the moon.

original: na jātu śikṣāpratipanna evaṃ mamātmajaṃ tyaja nameta śrāvakaḥ //
analyzed: na jātu śikṣā pratipannaḥ evam mama ātmajam tyaja nameta śrāvakaḥ
translated: In the same way, one who is engaged in my training should never abandon my son and worship a śrāvaka.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa sadevako loko kācamaṇikasya parikarma kuryāt na jātu sa kācamaṇiko vaiḍūryamaṇiratno bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa sa devakaḥ kāca maṇikasya parikarma kuryāt na jātu sa kāca maṇikaḥ vaiḍūrya maṇi ratnaḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: Just as, O Kāśyapa, even if the world with its gods were to perform the consecration of a glass gem, that glass gem would never become a lapis lazuli gem,

original: evameva kāśyapa sarvaśīlaśikṣādhutaguṇasamādhisamanvāgato 'pi śrāvako na jātu sa bodhimaṇḍe niṣadyānuttarā samyaksambodhimabhisambotsyate /
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa sarva śīla śikṣā dhuta guṇa samādhi samanvāgataḥ pi śrāvakaḥ na jātu sa bodhimaṇḍe niṣadya anuttarā samyaksambodhim abhisambotsyate
translated: In the same way, O Kāśyapa, the Śrāvaka, even though endowed with all the virtues of morality, learning, meditation, and concentration, will never sit on the seat of enlightenment and attain supreme perfect enlightenment.

original: tatredamucyate
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: yathāpi loko parikarma kuryās sadevakaḥ kācamaṇisya śuddhaye /
analyzed: yathā api parikarma kuryāḥ sa devakaḥ kācamaṇisya śuddhaye
translated: Just as the world would perform the purification ritual for a glass gem,

original: na kāca vaiḍūrya kadāci bheṣyate anyādṛśī tasya sadeva jātiḥ
analyzed: na kāca vaiḍūrya kadācid bheṣyate anyādṛśī tasya sadā eva jātiḥ
translated: the glass will never become a lapis lazuli, its nature is different from that of the gods.

original: evaṃ hi śīlāśrutaddhyānayukto yaḥ śrāvaka sarvaguṇānvito 'pi /
analyzed: evam hi śīla aśru tad dhyāna yuktaḥ yaḥ sarva guṇa anvitaḥ
translated: In the same way, the Śrāvaka, endowed with all virtues, who is endowed with morality, learning, and meditation,

original: na bodhimaṇḍasthita māra jitvā bodhiṃ spṛśitvā sugato bhaviṣyati //
analyzed: na bodhimaṇḍa sthita māra jitvā bodhim spṛśitvā sugataḥ bhaviṣyati
translated: will not, having conquered Māra on the seat of enlightenment and touched enlightenment, become a Sugata.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa vaiḍūryasya mahāmaṇiratnasya parikarma kriyamāṇairbahuṇām tatra karṣāpaṇaśatasahasrāṇām āyadvāraṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa vaiḍūryasya mahā maṇi ratnasya parikarma kriyamāṇaiḥ bahuṇām tatra karṣāpaṇa śata sahasrāṇām āya dvāram bhavati
translated: O Kāśyapa, it is just as when the purification ritual is performed for a great precious gem of lapis lazuli, it becomes a source of income for many hundreds of thousands of Karṣāpaṇas.

original: evameva kāśyapa yatra bodhisattvasya parikarma kriyamāṇe bahūnāṃ tatra śrāvakapratyekabuddhaśatasahasrāṇām āyadvāraṃ bhavati /
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa yatra bodhisattvasya parikarma kriyamāṇe bahūnām tatra śrāvaka pratyekabuddha śata sahasrāṇām āya dvāram bhavati
translated: In the same way, O Kāśyapa, wherever the purification ritual of the Bodhisattva is performed, there it becomes a source of income for many hundreds of thousands of Śrāvakas and Pratyekabuddhas.

original: tatredamucyate
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: vaiḍūryaratne parikarmanīyante karṣāpaṇānāṃ ca bahu āyu bhoti /
analyzed: vaiḍūrya ratne karṣāpaṇānām ca
translated: When a lapis lazuli gem is being polished, it becomes more valuable than gold, and it is very useful for many years.

original: buddhorasānāṃ parikarmaṇaṃ tathā āyo bahūnāṃ śrāvakānāṃ tatheva / //
analyzed: buddha urasānām parikarmaṇam tathā āyaḥ bahūnām śrāvakānām tathā iva
translated: In the same way, when the Buddha's heart is being polished, it becomes very useful for many disciples.

original: KP / atha khalu bhagavān punarevāyuṣmantaṃ mahākāśyapam āmantrayati sma /
analyzed: atha khalu bhagavān punar eva āyuṣmantam mahākāśyapam āmantrayati sma
translated: Then the Blessed One again addressed the Venerable Mahakasyapa:

original: yasmiṃ kāśyapa deśe uṣṭradhūmaka kṛṣṇaśira uttānaśāyī bhavati sa deśa sopadravaḥ sopakleśa sopāyāso bhavati /
analyzed: yasmin kāśyapa deśe uṣṭradhūmaka kṛṣṇaśiraḥ uttāna śāyī bhavati sa deśa sa upadravaḥ sa upakleśa sa upāyāsaḥ bhavati
translated: In whatever country, O Kasyapa, the Ustradhumra, the Krishna-shira, and the Utan-shayi are, that country is afflicted, troubled, and distressed.

original: sacetpuna kāśyapa yasmiṃ deśe bodhisattvo bhavati /
analyzed: saced puna kāśyapa yasmin deśe bodhisattvaḥ bhavati
translated: But if, O Kasyapa, in whatever country there is a Bodhisattva,

original: sa deśa nirupadrava nirupakleśa nirupāyāso bhavati /
analyzed: sa deśa nirupadrava nirupakleśa nirupāyāsaḥ bhavati
translated: that country is free from affliction, free from trouble, and free from distress.

original: tasmāttarhi kāśyapa sattvārthodyuktena bodhisattvena bhavitavyaṃ tena sarvakuśalamūlāni sarvasattvānām utsraṣṭavyaṃ /
analyzed: tasmāt tarhi kāśyapa sattva artha udyuktena bodhisattvena bhavitavyam tena sarva kuśala mūlāni sarva sattvānām utsraṣṭavyam
translated: Therefore, O Kasyapa, a Bodhisattva who is zealous for the sake of beings should be so. He should give up all his wholesome roots for all beings,

original: sarvaṃ ca kuśalamūla samyaksamudānayitavyaṃ /
analyzed: sarvam ca kuśala mūla samyak samudānayitavyam
translated: and he should gather all wholesome roots completely.

original: yaśca jñānabheṣajyaṃ paryeṣate tena caturdiśam gatvā sarvasattvānāṃ bhūtacikitsā kartavyāḥ bhūtacikitsāyā cca sattvā cikitsitavyāḥ
analyzed: yaḥ ca jñāna bheṣajyam paryeṣate tena caturdiśam gatvā sarva sattvānām bhūta cikitsā kartavyāḥ bhūta cikitsāyāḥ ca sattvāḥ cikitsitavyāḥ
translated: Whoever seeks the medicine of wisdom should go to the four directions and practice the true treatment for all beings. And by the true treatment, beings should be treated.

original: KP / tatra kāśyapaḥ katamā bhūtacikitsāḥ yaduta rāgasya aśubhā cikitsā /
analyzed: tatra kāśyapaḥ katamāḥ bhūta cikitsāḥ yat uta rāgasya aśubhā cikitsā
translated: Here, Kāśyapa, what is the true treatment? Namely, the impurity treatment for passion,

original: dveṣasya maitrī cikitsāḥ mohasya pratītyasamutpādapratyavekṣaṇā cikitsāḥ sarvadṛṣṭīgatānāṃ
analyzed: dveṣasya maitrī cikitsāḥ mohasya pratītyasamutpāda pratyavekṣaṇā cikitsāḥ sarva dṛṣṭīgatānām
translated: the loving-kindness treatment for hatred, the dependent origination contemplation treatment for delusion,

original: śūnyatā cikitsāḥ sarvakalpavikalpaparikalpārambhaṇavitarkamanasīkārāṇām ānimitta🔽cikitsāḥ sarvakāmadhāturūpadhātvārūpyadhātuprahāṇāyām apraṇihita cikitsāḥ sarvaviparyāsānā
analyzed: śūnyatā cikitsāḥ sarva kalpa vikalpa parikalpa ārambhaṇa vitarka manasīkārāṇām  cikitsāḥ sarva kāmadhātu rūpadhātu ārūpyadhātu prahāṇāyām apraṇihita cikitsāḥ sarva viparyāsānā
translated: the emptiness treatment for all views, the signlessness treatment for all conceptual thoughts, imaginations, fabrications, and mental engagements,🔽the wishlessness treatment for abandoning all the desire realm, form realm, and formless realm, the four inversions treatment for all inversions,

original: catvāro viparyāsa cikitsāḥ anitye nityasañjñāyāḥ anityāḥ sarvasaṃskārā iti cikitsāḥ
analyzed: catvāraḥ viparyāsa cikitsāḥ anitye nitya sañjñāyāḥ anityāḥ sarva saṃskārāḥ iti cikitsāḥ
translated: the impermanence treatment for the perception of permanence in the impermanent, the impermanence treatment for all conditioned things,

original: duḥkhe sukhasañjñāyā duḥkhā sarvasaṃskārā iti cikitsāḥ anātmīye ātmīyasañjñāyā anātmāna
analyzed: duḥkhe sukha sañjñāyāḥ sarva saṃskārāḥ iti cikitsāḥ anātmīye ātmīya sañjñāyāḥ
translated: the suffering treatment for the perception of happiness in suffering, the suffering treatment for all conditioned things, the non-self treatment for the perception of self in the insubstantial,

original: sarvadharmā iti cikitsāḥ aśubhe śubhasañjñāyāḥ śāntaṃ nirvāṇam iti cikitsāḥ
analyzed: sarva dharmāḥ iti cikitsāḥ aśubhe śubha sañjñāyāḥ śāntam nirvāṇam iti cikitsāḥ
translated: All dharmas are the treatment for the perception of purity in impurity. The cessation of suffering is the treatment for the perception of nirvana as peace.

original: KP / catvāri smṛtyupasthānāni kāyevedanācittadharmasanniśritānāṃ cikitsāḥ kāye kāyānupasyī viharati na ca kāye kāyānupāśyanāyām ātmyadṛṣṭyāṃ 🔽patati /
analyzed: catvāri smṛti upasthānāni kāye vedanā citta dharma sanniśritānām cikitsāḥ kāye kāya anupasyī viharati na ca kāye kāya anupāśyanāyām ātmya dṛṣṭyām  patati
translated: The four establishments of mindfulness are the treatment for those who rely on body, feelings, mind, and dharmas. Abiding in observing the body in the body, one does not fall into the view of self in observing the body.

original: vedanāyāṃ vedanānupaśyī viharati na ca vedanānupaśyanāyā ātmadṛṣṭīgatena patati /
analyzed: vedanāyām vedanā anupaśyī viharati na ca vedanā anupaśyanāyāḥ ātma dṛṣṭī gatena patati
translated: In observing feelings, one abides, but does not fall into the view of self in observing feelings.

original: citte cittānupaśyī viharati na ca cittānupaśyanāyāṃ jīvadiṣṭīye patati /
analyzed: citte citta anupaśyī viharati na ca citta anupaśyanāyām jīvadiṣṭīye patati
translated: Abiding in observing the mind, one does not fall into the view of a living being in observing the mind.

original: dharme dharmānupaśyī viharati na ca dharmānupaśyanāyāṃ pudgaladṛṣṭīye patati /
analyzed: dharme dharma anupaśyī viharati na ca dharma anupaśyanāyām pudgaladṛṣṭīye patati
translated: Abiding in observing dharmas, one does not fall into the view of a person in observing dharmas.

original: catvāri samyakprahāṇāni sarvākuśaladharmaprahāṇāya cikitsā /
analyzed: catvāri samyakprahāṇāni sarva akuśala dharma prahāṇāya cikitsā
translated: The four right efforts are the treatment for abandoning all unwholesome dharmas.

original: sarvakuśaladharmapāripūryaiḥ saṃvartante /
analyzed: sarva kuśala dharma pāripūryaiḥ saṃvartante
translated: They lead to the fulfillment of all wholesome dharmas.

original: catvāro dṛddhipādāḥ kāyacittapiṇḍagrāhotsargāya saṃvate /
analyzed: catvāraḥ dṛddhipādāḥ kāya citta piṇḍa grāha utsargāya
translated: The four bases of supernatural power lead to the relinquishment of grasping at the body and mind as a whole.

original: cikitsāḥ pañcendriyāṇi pañca balāni aśrādvyakausīdyamuṣitasmṛticittavikṣepaasamprajanyatāduṣprajñātācikitsāḥ🔽sapta bodhyaṅgāni dharmasamūhājñānasya cikitsāḥ āryāṣṭāṅgo mārga dauṣprajñāsarvaparapravādināṃ
analyzed: cikitsāḥ pañca indriyāṇi pañca balāni aśrādvya kausīdya muṣita smṛti citta vikṣepa asamprajanya tā duṣprajñātā cikitsāḥ  sapta bodhyaṅgāni dharma samūha ajñānasya cikitsāḥ ārya aṣṭāṅgaḥ mārga dauṣprajñā sarva para pravādinām
translated: The five faculties, the five powers, the remedies for lack of faith, laziness, forgetfulness, distraction, and lack of wisdom.

original: kumārgapratipannānāṃ cikitsāḥ iyamucyate kāśyapa bhūtacikitsāḥ tatra kāśyapa bodhisattvena yogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ
analyzed: kumārga pratipannānām cikitsāḥ iyam ucyate kāśyapa bhūta cikitsāḥ tatra kāśyapa bodhisattvena yogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ
translated: The seven factors of awakening are the remedies for the mass of ignorance about phenomena. The noble eightfold path is the remedy for all wrong views and for those who have entered the wrong path. This, Kāśyapa, is called the true remedy. There, Kāśyapa, the bodhisattva should practice.

original: KP / yāvanta kāśyapa jāmbudvīpe vaidyā vā vaidyāntevāsino vā sarveṣāṃ teṣām jivako vaidyarājā agro mākhyāyate /
analyzed: yāvanta kāśyapa jāmbudvīpe vaidyāḥ vā vaidya antevāsinaḥ vā sarveṣām teṣām jivakaḥ vaidya rājā agraḥ mā ākhyāyate
translated: As many physicians or physician apprentices as there are in Jambudvīpa, all of them are proclaimed to be like Jīvaka, the king of physicians.

original: yāvantaḥ kāśyapa trisāhasramahāsāhasrāyāṃ lokadhātau sattvāḥ te sarve jīvakavaidyarājasadṛśā bhaveyuḥ te sarve paripṛccheran /
analyzed: yāvantaḥ kāśyapa tri sāhasra mahā sāhasrāyām lokadhātau sattvāḥ te sarve jīvaka vaidya rāja sadṛśāḥ bhaveyuḥ te sarve paripṛccheran
translated: As many beings as there are in the great trichiliocosm, all of them would be like Jīvaka, the king of physicians. All of them would ask:

original: dṛṣṭkaukṛtyapratiṣṭhitasya prapatitasya kiṃ bhaiṣajyam iti /
analyzed: dṛṣṭ kaukṛtya pratiṣṭhitasya prapatitasya kim bhaiṣajyam iti
translated: What is the medicine for one who has fallen, based on remorse and regret?

original: te na samarthā na ca śaknoti tam artha ākhyātuṃ vā nirdeṣṭuṃ vā jñānavijñātā vā /
analyzed: te na samarthāḥ na ca śaknoti tam arthe ākhyātum vā nirdeṣṭum vā jñāna vijñātā vā
translated: They are not able and cannot explain or demonstrate that meaning with knowledge and understanding.

original: tatra kāśyapa bodhisattvenaivam upaparikṣitavya na mayā lokikabhaiṣajyasantuṣṭirveditavyā /
analyzed: tatra kāśyapa bodhisattvena evam upaparikṣitavya na mayā lokika bhaiṣajya santuṣṭiḥ veditavyā
translated: There, Kāśyapa, a bodhisattva should investigate thus: 'I should not be satisfied with worldly medicine.

original: lokottara mayā jñānabhaiṣajyaṃ paryeṣṭitavyaṃ sarvakuśalamūlaṃ ca samyaksamudānayitavyam /
analyzed: lokottara mayā jñāna bhaiṣajyam paryeṣṭitavyam sarva kuśala mūlam ca samyak samudānayitavyam
translated: I should seek the supramundane medicine of knowledge and gather all the roots of virtue.'

original: mityevaṃ copaparīkṣitavyaḥ yacca jñānabhaiṣajyaṃ samudānayitvā tena caturdiśaṃ gatvā sarvasattvānāṃ bhūtacikitsā kartavyāḥ bhūtacikitsayā ca
analyzed: miti evam ca upaparīkṣitavyaḥ yat ca jñāna bhaiṣajyam samudānayitvā tena caturdiśam gatvā sarva sattvānām bhūta cikitsā kartavyāḥ bhūta cikitsayā ca
translated: And he should investigate thus: 'Having gathered the medicine of knowledge, I should go to the four directions and treat all beings with the medicine of truth.'

original: sattvāni cikitsitavyāḥ
analyzed: sattvāni cikitsitavyāḥ
translated: And he should treat beings with the medicine of truth.

original: KP / tatra kataraṃ lokottaraṃ jñānabhaiṣajyaṃ /
analyzed: tatra kataram lokottaram jñāna bhaiṣajyam
translated: Now, what is the supramundane medicine of knowledge?

original: yadidaṃ hetupratyayajñānaḥ nairātmyeniḥsattvaḥnirjīvaniṣpoṣanīṣpudgaleṣu dharmeṣvadhimuktijñānaṃ /
analyzed: yat idam hetu pratyaya jñānaḥ dharmeṣu adhimukti jñānam
translated: It is the knowledge of the causes and conditions, the knowledge of faith in the teachings of non-self, non-sentience, non-living being, non-person,

original: śūnyatānupalambheṣu dharmeṣu anutrāsaḥ cittaparigaveṣatāye vīryaṃ /
analyzed: śūnyatā anupalambheṣu dharmeṣu anutrāsaḥ vīryam
translated: the non-fear in the teachings of emptiness and non-apprehension, the effort to search for the mind.

original: sa evaṃ cittaṃ parigaveṣate /
analyzed: saḥ evam cittam parigaveṣate
translated: He searches for the mind thus:

original: kataraṃ cittaṃ rajyati vā duṣyati vā muhyati vā /
analyzed: katarat cittam rajyati vā duṣyati vā muhyati vā
translated: 'Which mind is defiled, corrupted, or deluded?

original: atītaṃ vā anāgataṃ vā pratyutpannaṃ vā /
analyzed: atītam vā anāgatam vā pratyutpannam vā
translated: Is it past, future, or present?'

original: yadi tāvad atītaṃ cittaṃ tatkṣīṇaṃ /
analyzed: yadi tāvat atītam cittam tat kṣīṇam
translated: If the past mind is exhausted,

original: yādanāgataṃ cittaṃ tadasamprāptaḥ atha pratyutpannasya cittasya sthitirnāsti /
analyzed: yāt anāgatam cittam tat asamprāptaḥ atha pratyutpannasya cittasya sthitiḥ na asti
translated: and the future mind is not yet arisen, and the present mind does not remain,

original: KP / cittaṃ hi kāśyapa na bahirdhā nobhayāyomantarāle upalabhyate /
analyzed: cittam hi kāśyapa na bahirdhā na ubhaya ayomantarāle upalabhyate
translated: Mind, O Kāśyapa, is not perceived either outside or in the two, nor in between.

original: cittaṃ hi kāśyapa arūpyanidarśanam apratigham anābhāsam avijñāptikam apratiṣṭhitam
analyzed: cittam hi kāśyapa arūpya nidarśanam apratigham anābhāsam avijñāptikam apratiṣṭhitam
translated: Mind, O Kāśyapa, is formless, invisible, unobstructing, non-apparent, non-resistant,

original: aniketaḥ cittaṃ hi kāśyapa sarvabuddhairna dṛṣṭaṃ na paśyanti na paśyiṣyanti na drakṣyanti
analyzed: aniketaḥ cittam hi kāśyapa sarva buddhaiḥ na dṛṣṭam na paśyanti na paśyiṣyanti na drakṣyanti
translated: unfixed, and without abode. Mind, O Kāśyapa, has not been seen by all the Buddhas, is not seen, will not be seen, and is not seen.

original: yatsarvabuddhairna dṛṣtaṃ na paśyanti na drakṣyanti kīdṛśastasya pracāro draṣṭavyaṃ
analyzed: yat sarva buddhaiḥ na dṛṣtam na paśyanti na drakṣyanti kīdṛśaḥ tasya pracāraḥ draṣṭavyam
translated: What is not seen by all the Buddhas, is not seen, will not be seen, and is not seen, what kind of activity should be seen in that?

original: nānyatra vitathaviparyāsapatitāyā santatyā dharmāḥ pravartante cittaṃ hi kāśyapa
analyzed: na anyatra vitatha viparyāsa patitāyā santatyā dharmāḥ pravartante cittam hi kāśyapa
translated: Apart from that, dharmas proceed in a continuum that has fallen into error and perversion. Mind, O Kāśyapa,

original: māyāsadṛśamm abhūtaṃ vikalpya vividhopapattiṃ parigṛhṇāti cittaṃ hi kāśyapa vāyusadṛśaṃ
analyzed: māyā sadṛśam abhūtam vikalpya vividha upapattim parigṛhṇāti cittam hi kāśyapa vāyu sadṛśam
translated: is like an illusion, having arisen from unreal imagination, it takes on various rebirths. Mind, O Kāśyapa, is like the wind,

original: dūraṅgamam agrāhyam apracāra cittaṃ hi kāśyapa nadīsrotasadṛśamm anavastitam utpannaṃ
analyzed: dūraṅgamam agrāhyam apracāra cittam hi kāśyapa nadī srota sadṛśam anavastitam utpannam
translated: going far, ungraspable, and without movement. Mind, O Kāśyapa, is like the current of a river, not remaining, arisen,

original: bhagnavilīna cittaṃ hi kāśyapa pradīpārciḥsadṛśaṃ hetupratyayatayā pravartate / jvalati ca🔽KP / cittaṃ hi kāśyapa vidyusadṛśa kṣaṇabhaṅgāvyavasthitaṃ /
analyzed: bhagna vilīna cittam hi kāśyapa pradīpa arciḥ sadṛśam hetu pratyaya tayā pravartate jvalati ca  cittam hi kāśyapa kṣaṇa bhaṅga avyavasthitam
translated: The mind, Kāśyapa, is like a lamp flame, arising and ceasing through causes and conditions.🔽The mind, Kāśyapa, is like lightning, breaking up and unstable.

original: cittaṃ hi kāśyapa ākāśasadṛśam āgantukerupakleśe saṅkiśyate cittaṃ hi kāśyapa vānarasadṛśa
analyzed: cittam hi kāśyapa ākāśa sadṛśam saṅkiśyate cittam hi kāśyapa vānara sadṛśa
translated: The mind, Kāśyapa, is like the sky, defiled by adventitious afflictions.🔽The mind, Kāśyapa, is like a monkey, desiring objects and various actions.

original: viṣayābhilāṣi vicitrakarmasaṃsthānatayā cittaṃ hi kāśyapa citrakārsadṛśa vicitrakarmābhisaṃskaraṇatayā /
analyzed: viṣaya abhilāṣi vicitra karma saṃsthāna tayā cittam hi kāśyapa vicitra karma abhisaṃskaraṇa tayā
translated: The mind, Kāśyapa, is like a painter, creating various karmic formations.

original: cittaṃ hi kāśyapa anavasthitaṃ nānākleśapravartanatayā cittaṃ hi kāśyapa ekacaram
analyzed: cittam hi kāśyapa anavasthitam nānā kleśa pravartana tayā cittam hi kāśyapa ekacaram
translated: The mind, Kāśyapa, is unstable, engaging in various afflictions. The mind, Kāśyapa, moves alone,

original: advitīyacittābhisandhānatayā cittaṃ hi kāśyapa rājasadṛśaṃ sarvadharmādhipateyā
analyzed: advitīya citta abhisandhāna tayā cittam hi kāśyapa rāja sadṛśam sarva dharma ādhipateyā
translated: not being associated with a second mind. The mind, Kāśyapa, is like a king, being the lord of all phenomena.

original: cittaṃ hi kāśyapa amitrasadṛśaṃ sarvaduḥkhasañjananatayā
analyzed: cittam hi kāśyapa amitra sadṛśam sarva duḥkha sañjanana tayā
translated: The mind, Kāśyapa, is like an enemy, producing all suffering.

original: KP / cittaṃ hi kāśyapa pāṃsvāgārasadṛśam anitye nityasañjñayā cittam hi kāśyapa
analyzed: cittam hi kāśyapa pāṃsu āgāra sadṛśam anitye nitya sañjñayā cittam hi kāśyapa
translated: The mind, Kāśyapa, is like a house of excrement, perceiving permanence in impermanence. The mind, Kāśyapa,🔽is like a dream, perceiving pleasure in suffering. The mind, Kāśyapa, is like an empty town, perceiving self in non-self.

original: nīlamakṣikāsadṛśam aśuco śucisañjñāyā cittaṃ hi kāśyapa matsyabaḍīśasadṛśa duḥkhe
analyzed: nīla makṣikā sadṛśam cittam hi kāśyapa duḥkhe
translated: The mind is like a bluebottle fly, O Kāśyapa, in that it perceives what is impure as pure. The mind is like a fish-hook, O Kāśyapa, in that it perceives what is suffering as happiness.

original: sukhasañjñāyā cittaṃ hi kāśyapa svapnasadṛśam anātmīye ātmīyasañjñāyā cittaṃ🔽hi kāśyapa pratyarthikasadṛśam vividhakāraṇākaraṇatayā cittaṃ hi kāśyapa ojāhārayakṣasadṛśa
analyzed: sukha sañjñāyāḥ cittam hi kāśyapa svapna sadṛśam anātmīye ātmīya sañjñāyāḥ cittam  hi kāśyapa pratyarthika sadṛśam vividha kāraṇa akaraṇa tayā cittam hi kāśyapa ojā āhāra yakṣa sadṛśa
translated: The mind is like a dream, O Kāśyapa, in that it perceives what is non-self as self.

original: sadāvatāragaveṣaṇatayā cittaṃ hi kāśyapa arisadṛśaṃ sadā cchidrārāmagaveṣaṇatayā
analyzed: sadā avatāra gaveṣaṇa tayā cittam hi kāśyapa ari sadṛśam sadā chidra ārāma gaveṣaṇa tayā
translated: The mind is like an enemy, O Kāśyapa, in that it always seeks an opportunity to harm. The mind is like a variety of causes and actions, O Kāśyapa, in that it is always seeking an opportunity to harm. The mind is like a yakṣa that feeds on vital energy, O Kāśyapa,

original: KP / cittaṃ hi kāśyapa sadā unnatāvanatam anunayapratighopahataṃ cittaṃ hi kāśyapa
analyzed: cittam hi kāśyapa sadā unnata avanatam anunaya pratigha upahatam cittam hi kāśyapa
translated: in that it always seeks an opportunity to enter. The mind is like an enemy, O Kāśyapa, in that it always seeks an opportunity to harm.

original: corasadṛśa sarvakuśalamūlamuṣaṇatayā cittaṃ hi kāśyapa rūpārāma pagataṅganetrasadṛśaṃ
analyzed: cittam hi kāśyapa cittam hi kāśyapa
translated: The mind is always high and low, O Kāśyapa, afflicted by attachment and aversion. The mind is like a thief, O Kāśyapa, in that it steals all wholesome roots. The mind is like a peacock's feather, O Kāśyapa, in that it delights in form.

original: cittaṃ hi kāśyapa śabdārāma saṅgrāmabherīsadṛśa cittaṃ hi kāśyapa sadā gandhārāma
analyzed: cittam hi kāśyapa śabda ārāma saṅgrāma bherī sadṛśa cittam hi kāśyapa sadā gandha ārāma
translated: The mind is like a battle drum, O Kāśyapa, in that it delights in sound. The mind is always delighted by smell, O Kāśyapa,

original: varāha iva mīḍakuṇape cittaṃ hi kāśyapa rasārāma rasabhojyaceṭīsadṛśaṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: varāhe iva mīḍa kuṇape cittam hi kāśyapa rasa ārāma rasa bhojya ceṭī sadṛśam cittam
translated: like a pig in a heap of filth. The mind is like a servant who enjoys flavors, O Kāśyapa, in that it delights in tastes.

original: hi kāśyapa sparṣārāma makṣikeva tailapātre
analyzed: hi kāśyapa makṣikā iva taila pātre
translated: Kāśyapa, the mind is like a fly that enjoys contact with a vessel of oil.

original: KP / cittaṃ hi kāśyapa parigaveṣamaṇaṃ na labhyate yanna labhyate tannopalabhyate tannātītaṃ nānāgataṃ na pratyutpannaṃ /
analyzed: cittam hi kāśyapa parigaveṣamaṇam na labhyate yat na labhyate tat na upalabhyate tat na atītam na anāgatam na pratyutpannam
translated: Kāśyapa, the mind is sought after but not found. What is not found is not perceived. That is not past, not future, not present.

original: yannātītaṃ nānāgataṃ na pratyutpannaṃ tatradhvasamatikrāntaṃ yatryadhvasamatikrāntaṃ /
analyzed: yat na atītam na anāgatam na pratyutpannam tatra adhva samatikrāntam yatri adhva samatikrāntam
translated: What is not past, not future, not present, that transcends the three times. What transcends the three times

original: tannaivāsti neva nāsti /
analyzed: tat na eva asti na iva na asti
translated: is neither existent nor non-existent.

original: yannaivāsti na nāsti /
analyzed: yat na eva asti na na asti
translated: What is neither existent nor non-existent

original: tadajātaṃ yadajātaṃ /
analyzed: tat a jātam yat a jātam
translated: is unborn. What is unborn

original: tasya nāsti svabhāvaḥ yasya nāsti svabhāvaḥ tasya nāstyutpāda /🔽yasya nāstyutpādaḥ tasya nāsti nirodhaḥ yasya nāsti nirodhaḥ tasya nāsti vigamaḥ
analyzed: tasya na asti svabhāvaḥ yasya na asti svabhāvaḥ tasya na asti utpāda  yasya na asti utpādaḥ tasya na asti nirodhaḥ yasya na asti nirodhaḥ tasya na asti vigamaḥ
translated: has no intrinsic nature. What has no intrinsic nature has no origination.🔽What has no origination has no cessation. What has no cessation has no separation.

original: avigamastasyarna gatirnāgatirna cyutirnopapattiḥ yatra na gatirnāgatirna cyutirnopapattiḥ
analyzed: avigamaḥ tasyar na gatiḥ na agatiḥ na cyutiḥ na upapattiḥ yatra na gatiḥ na agatiḥ na cyutiḥ na upapattiḥ
translated: What has no separation has no going, no coming, no passing away, no rebirth. Where there is no going, no coming, no passing away, no rebirth,

original: tatra na kecit saṃskārāḥ yatra na kecit saṃskārāḥ tadasaṃskṛtaṃ /
analyzed: tatra na kecid saṃskārāḥ yatra na kecid saṃskārāḥ tat asaṃskṛtam
translated: there are no conditioned things. Where there are no conditioned things, that is unconditioned.

original: tadāryāṇāṃ gotra
analyzed: tad āryāṇām gotra
translated: That is the lineage of the noble ones.

original: KP / ya āryāṇāṃ gotra /
analyzed: yaḥ āryāṇām gotra
translated: What is the lineage of the noble ones,

original: tatrarna śikṣā na niśrayo nāniśrayaḥ yatra na śikṣā na niḥśrayo nāniśrayaḥ tatra🔽na śikṣāvyatikramaḥ yatra na śikṣāvyatikramaḥ tatra na saṃvaro nāsaṃvaraḥ yatra na saṃvaro nāsaṃvara /
analyzed: tatrar na śikṣā na niśrayaḥ na aniśrayaḥ yatra na śikṣā na niḥśrayaḥ na aniśrayaḥ tatra  na śikṣā vyatikramaḥ yatra na śikṣā vyatikramaḥ tatra na saṃvaraḥ na a saṃvaraḥ yatra na saṃvaraḥ na a saṃvaraḥ
translated: There is no training, no reliance, and no non-reliance. Where there is no training, no reliance, and no non-reliance,🔽there is no transgression of training. Where there is no transgression of training, there is no restraint and no non-restraint. Where there is no restraint and no non-restraint,

original: tatra na cāro nācāraḥ na pracāraḥ yatra na cāro nācāra na pracāraḥ tatra na cittaṃ
analyzed: tatra na cāraḥ na ācāraḥ na pracāraḥ yatra na cāraḥ na ācāra na pracāraḥ tatra na cittam
translated: there is no conduct and no non-conduct, no practice. Where there is no conduct, no non-conduct, and no practice, there is no mind

original: na cetasikā dharmāḥ yatra na cittaṃ na cetasikā dharmāḥ tatra na mano na vijñānaḥ
analyzed: na cetasikāḥ dharmāḥ yatra na cittam na cetasikāḥ dharmāḥ tatra na manaḥ na vijñānaḥ
translated: and no mental factors. Where there is no mind and no mental factors, there is no mind and no consciousness.

original: yatra na mano na vijñāna /
analyzed: yatra na manaḥ na vijñāna
translated: Where there is no mind and no consciousness,

original: tatra na karmo na vipākaḥ yatra na karmo na vipākaḥ tatra na sukhaṃ na duḥkhaṃ yatra
analyzed: tatra na karmaḥ na vipākaḥ yatra na karmaḥ na vipākaḥ tatra na sukham na duḥkham yatra
translated: there is no action and no result. Where there is no action and no result, there is no pleasure and no pain. Where

original: na sukhaṃ na duḥkhaṃ tadāryāṇāṃ gotraṃ yadāryānāṃ gotraṃ tatra na karmo na karmābhisaṃskāro
analyzed: na sukham na duḥkham tat āryāṇām gotram yat āryānām gotram tatra na karmaḥ na karma abhisaṃskāraḥ
translated: there is no pleasure and no pain, that is the lineage of the noble ones. Where that is the lineage of the noble ones, there is no action and no formation of action,

original: nāpi tatra gotre kāyena karma kṛyate na vācā na manasā /
analyzed: na api tatra gotre kāyena karma kṛyate na vācā na manasā
translated: and in that lineage, action is not done by the body, speech, or mind.

original: nāpi tatra gotre hīnotkṛṣṭamadhyamavyavasthānaṃ samaṃ tadgotram ākāśasamatayā /
analyzed: na api tatra gotre hīna utkṛṣṭa madhyama vyavasthānam samam tat gotram ākāśa sama tayā
translated: And in that lineage, there is no establishment of inferior, superior, or middling, that lineage is equal, equal to space.

original: nirviśeṣaṃ tadgotraṃ sarvadharmaikarasatayā /
analyzed: nirviśeṣam tat gotram sarva dharma eka rasa tayā
translated: That spiritual lineage is undifferentiated, because all phenomena have one taste.

original: KP / viviktaṃ tadgotraṃ kāyacittavivekatayā /
analyzed: viviktam tat gotram kāya citta viveka tayā
translated: That spiritual lineage is secluded, because of the seclusion of body and mind.

original: anulomaṃ tadgotraṃ nirvāṇasya /
analyzed: anulomam tat gotram nirvāṇasya
translated: That spiritual lineage is in accord with nirvana.

original: vimalaṃ tadgotraṃ sarvakleśamalavigata amamaṃ tadgotram ahaṅkāramamakāravigataṃ /
analyzed: vimalam tad gotram sarva kleśa mala vigata amamam tad gotram ahaṅkāra mamakāra vigatam
translated: That spiritual lineage is stainless, being free from the stains of all afflictions. It is free from possessions, being free from the notion of I and the notion of mine.

original: aviṣamaṃ tadgotraṃ bhūtābhūtasamatayā niryātaṃ satyaṃ tadgotraṃ paramārthasatyayā /
analyzed: aviṣamam tat gotram bhūta abhūta sama tayā niryātam satyam tat gotram paramārtha satyayā
translated: That spiritual lineage is not uneven, because it is dedicated to the equality of what is real and what is not real. It is true, because it is the ultimate truth.

original: akṣayaṃ tadgotra atyantatānutpannaṃ /
analyzed: akṣayam tad gotra atyanta tā anutpannam
translated: That spiritual lineage is inexhaustible, because it is absolutely unarisen.

original: nityaṃ tadgotraṃ sadā dharmatathatayā /
analyzed: nityam tad gotram sadā dharma tathatayā
translated: That spiritual lineage is eternal, because it is always the suchness of phenomena.

original: aśubhaṃ tadgotraṃ nirvāṇaparamatayā /
analyzed: aśubham tad gotram nirvāṇa parama tayā
translated: That spiritual lineage is inauspicious, because it is dedicated to nirvana.

original: śubhaṃ tadgotraṃ sarvākāramalavigataṃ /
analyzed: śubham tat gotram sarva ākāra mala vigatam
translated: That spiritual lineage is auspicious, being free from all kinds of stains.

original: anātmā tadgotram ātmanaḥ parigaveṣyamāṇanupalambhāt /
analyzed: anātmā tad gotram ātmanaḥ
translated: That spiritual lineage is non-self, because the self is not perceived when sought.

original: viśuddhaṃ tadgotram atyantaviśuddhatayā //
analyzed: viśuddham tad gotram atyanta viśuddha tayā
translated: That spiritual lineage is pure, because of its absolute purity.

original: KP / adhyātmaṃ kāśyapa parimargatha mā bahirvidhāvadhvaṃ /
analyzed: adhyātmam kāśyapa parimargatha mā bahis vidhāvadhvam
translated: Kāśyapa, search inwardly, do not run around externally.

original: tatkasmāddhetoḥ bhaviṣyanti kāśyapa anāgate dhvani bhikṣavaḥ śvaloṣṭvānujavanasadṛśāḥ kathaṃ ca kāśyapa bhikṣavaḥ śvaloṣṭānujavanasadṛśā bhavati
analyzed: tat kasmāt hetoḥ bhaviṣyanti kāśyapa anāgate dhvani bhikṣavaḥ śva loṣṭu ānuja vana sadṛśāḥ katham ca kāśyapa bhikṣavaḥ śva loṣṭu ānuja vana sadṛśāḥ bhavati
translated: What is the reason for that? Kāśyapa, in the future there will be monks who are like dogs chasing clods. Kāśyapa, how are monks like dogs chasing clods?

original: tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa śvāno loṣṭunā trāsitaḥ tameva loṣṭuranudhāvati /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa śvānaḥ loṣṭunā trāsitaḥ tam eva loṣṭuḥ anudhāvati
translated: It is just as, Kāśyapa, a dog, frightened by a clod, runs after that very clod.

original: na tamanudhāvati /
analyzed: na tam anudhāvati
translated: It does not run after

original: yena sa loṣṭuṃ kṣiptaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yena sa loṣṭum kṣiptam bhavati
translated: the one who threw the clod.

original: evameva kāśyapa satyeke śramaṇabrāhmaṇā ye rūpaśabdagandharasasparśairbhayabhītā araṇyāyataneṣu viharanti /
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa sati eke śramaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ ye rūpa śabda gandha rasa sparśaiḥ bhaya bhītāḥ araṇya āyataneṣu viharanti
translated: In the same way, Kāśyapa, there are some ascetics and brahmins who, frightened by the fear of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, dwell in the forests.

original: teṣā tatrekākinām advitīyānāṃ kāyapraviviktavihāriṇāṃ rajanīyāstajjakriyā rupaśabdagandharasasparśāvabhāsam āgacchanti /
analyzed: teṣām tatra ekākinām advitīyānām kāya pravivikta vihāriṇām rajanīyāḥ tad ja kriyāḥ rupa śabda gandha rasa sparśa avabhāsam āgacchanti
translated: For them, there, alone, without a second, dwelling in bodily seclusion, desirable forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches appear.

original: te tatrāvekṣakāḥ sukhalikānuyogam anuyuktā viharanti ranti /
analyzed: te tatra avekṣakāḥ sukhalikā anuyogam anuyuktāḥ viharanti ranti
translated: There, they, looking on, dwell engaged in the practice of pleasure, delighting.

original: KP / te na jāna jānanti na buddhyanti kiṃ rūpāśabdagandharasasparśāna nīḥsaraṇam iti /
analyzed: te na jāna jānanti na iti
translated: They do not know, do not understand, what is the escape from forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches.

original: te ajānantaḥ abuddhyantaḥ teṣāṃ rūpaśabdagandharasasparśānāsvādaṃ cādīnavaṃ cā niḥsaraṇaṃ
analyzed: te a jānantaḥ a buddhyantaḥ teṣām rūpa śabda gandha rasa sparśa an āsvādam ca ādīnavam ca niḥsaraṇam
translated: They, not knowing, not understanding, the disadvantages and the escape in regard to those forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tangibles,

original: ca avatīrṇā grāmanagaranigamarāṣarājadhāniṣva punareva rūpaśabdagandharasasparśarhannyaṃ
analyzed: ca avatīrṇāḥ grāma nagara nigama rāṣa rājadhāniṣu punar eva
translated: having descended into villages, towns, cities, and capital cities, again experience forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tangibles,

original: saced araṇyagatā kālaṃ kurvanti /
analyzed: saced araṇya gatā kālam kurvanti
translated: if they die while in the forest,

original: teṣāṃ lokikasaṃvarasthitānā svargaloke upapattirbhavati /
analyzed: teṣām lokika saṃvara sthitānām svarga loke upapattiḥ bhavati
translated: they, abiding in worldly morality, will be reborn in the heavenly world.

original: te tatrāpi divyaiḥ pañcabhiḥ kāmaguṇairhanyaṃ /🔽te tataścyutā aparimuktā samānāścaturbhirapāyairnirayatiryag niyamalokāsuraiḥ evaṃ hi kāśyapa bhikṣavaḥ śvaloṣṭvanujavanasadṛśā bhavanti /🔽KP / katham ca kāśyapa bhikṣurna śvaloṣṭvanujavanasadṛśo bhavati yaḥ kāśyapa bhikṣu ākruṣṭo na pratyākrośati tāḍito na pratitāḍayati paṃsito
analyzed: te tatra api divyaiḥ pañcabhiḥ kāma guṇaiḥ  te tatas cyutāḥ a parimuktā samānāḥ caturbhiḥ apāyaiḥ niraya tiryak niyama loka āsuraiḥ evam hi kāśyapa bhikṣavaḥ śva loṣṭu anuja vana sadṛśāḥ bhavanti  katham ca kāśyapa bhikṣuḥ na śva loṣṭu anuja vana sadṛśaḥ bhavati yaḥ kāśyapa bhikṣu ākruṣṭaḥ na pratyākrośati tāḍitaḥ na pratitāḍayati
translated: There, too, they will be intoxicated by the five divine sense objects.

original: na pratipaṃsayati /🔽bhaṇḍito na pratibhaṇḍayati /🔽roṣito na pratiroṣayati /
analyzed: na pratipaṃsayati 🔽bhaṇḍitaḥ na pratibhaṇḍayati 🔽roṣitaḥ na pratiroṣayati
translated: Having fallen from there, not being liberated, and not being free from the four lower realms—hell, animal realm, Yama world, and asura—in this way, Kāśyapa, monks are like dogs chasing clods.

original: ādhyātmaṃ cittaniddhyaptiṃ pratyavekṣate /🔽ko vākruṣṭo vā tāḍito vā /
analyzed: ādhyātmam citta niddhi aptim pratyavekṣate  kaḥ vā ākruṣṭaḥ vā tāḍitaḥ vā
translated: He examines the mental resolve within himself.🔽Who is it that is reviled, beaten,

original: paṃsito vā bhaṇḍito vā roṣito vā /
analyzed: paṃsitaḥ vā bhaṇḍitaḥ vā roṣitaḥ vā
translated: censured, scolded, or angered?

original: evaṃ hi kāśyapa bhikṣurna śvaloṣṭvanujavanasadṛśo bhavanasadṛśo bhavati /
analyzed: evam hi kāśyapa bhikṣuḥ na śva loṣṭu anuja vana sadṛśaḥ bhavana sadṛśaḥ bhavati
translated: In this way, Kāśyapa, a monk does not become like a dog chasing a clod, but becomes like a lion.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: śvāno yathā loṣṭuna trāsyamāno
analyzed: śvānaḥ yathā trāsyamānaḥ
translated: Just as a dog, frightened by a clod,

original: anudhāvate loṣṭu na yena kṣiptaṃ🔽em evihekai śramaṇā dvijā vā
analyzed: anudhāvate loṣṭu na yena kṣiptam  śramaṇāḥ dvijāḥ vā
translated: runs after the clod, not the one who threw it,🔽so too some ascetics and brahmins, frightened by form, etc.,

original: rūpādibhītā vanavāsam āśritā /
analyzed: rūpa ādi bhītā vana vāsam āśritā
translated: take up forest dwelling.

original: teṣāṃ ca tasmin vasatām araṇye
analyzed: teṣām ca tasmin vasatām araṇye
translated: But for them, while dwelling in the forest,

original: rūpādayo daśanam eta iṣṭā /🔽upekṣakādhyātmagate nabhijñā
analyzed: rūpa ādayaḥ daśanam ete iṣṭāḥ  upekṣaka adhyātma gate
translated: those very forms, etc., are desired.🔽Indifferent, ignorant of the inner,

original: ādīnavān niḥsaraṇeḥkam eṣā
analyzed: ādīnavāt eṣā
translated: not knowing the dangers, the escape from them,

original: ajānamānā puna grāmam āśritā /
analyzed: a jānamānā puna grāmam āśritā
translated: ignorant again, they return to the village,

original: punepi rūpehi vihanyamānā
analyzed: puna ipi rūpehi vihanyamānā
translated: again afflicted by forms, etc.

original: śyutaśca devai manujaiśca kecit
analyzed: śyutaḥ ca devaiḥ manujaiḥ ca kecid
translated: Some, fallen from the gods and humans,

original: tatrāpi divyān upabhujya bhogā
analyzed: tatra api divyān upabhujya bhogāḥ
translated: having enjoyed divine pleasures there,

original: apāyabhūmiḥ prapatanti kecit cyutā cyutā duḥkhamupaiti mūḍhāḥ
analyzed: apāya bhūmiḥ prapatanti kecid cyutā cyutā duḥkham upaiti mūḍhāḥ
translated: some fall to the realm of misfortune, fallen, the deluded one experiences suffering.

original: evaṃ hi te duḥkhaśatānubaddhā śvaloṣṭatulyā sugatena deśitā /
analyzed: evam hi te duḥkha śata anubaddhā śva loṣṭa tulyā sugatena deśitā
translated: Thus, bound by hundreds of sufferings, like a dog chasing a clod, they are taught by the Well-Gone One.

original: ākruṣṭa nākrośati tāḍitastathā na paṃsitaḥ paṃsayateśca kecit
analyzed: ākruṣṭa na ākrośati tāḍitaḥ tathā na paṃsitaḥ kecid
translated: When reviled, he does not revile in return; when beaten, he does not beat in return; when scolded, he does not scold in return.

original: na bhaṇḍito bhaṇḍayate tathānyān aroṣito roṣayate ca sūrataḥ
analyzed: na bhaṇḍitaḥ bhaṇḍayate tathā anyān a roṣitaḥ roṣayate ca sūratas
translated: When insulted, he does not insult others in return; when angered, he does not anger others in return.

original: adhyātmacittaṃ pratiprakṣataśca gaveṣate śāntatavi smṛtīmān
analyzed: adhyātma cittam pratiprakṣataḥ ca gaveṣate smṛtīmān
translated: With his mind well-subdued internally, he seeks peace, mindfulness, and tranquility.

original: evaṃvidhaḥ śīlavratopapaṇnoḥ na śvānatulya kathito jinena / //
analyzed: evaṃvidhaḥ na kathitaḥ jinena
translated: One who is endowed with such discipline and vows is not called a dog by the Victorious Ones.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa kuśalo aśvadamaka suto /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa kuśalaḥ
translated: Just as, for example, O Kāśyapa, a skilled horse trainer,

original: yatra yatra pṛthivīpradeśe aśva skhalati /
analyzed: yatra yatra pṛthivī pradeśe aśva skhalati
translated: wherever the horse stumbles,

original: utkumbhati vā khaḍuṅkakriyā vā karoti /
analyzed: utkumbhati vā khaḍuṅka kriyāḥ vā karoti
translated: or rears up, or acts recklessly,

original: tatra tatra caiva pṛthivīpradeśe nigṛhṇāti sa tathā tathā nigṛhṇāti yanna punarapi na prakupyate /
analyzed: tatra tatra ca eva pṛthivī pradeśe nigṛhṇāti sa tathā tathā nigṛhṇāti yat na punar api na prakupyate
translated: there, right there, he restrains it. He restrains it in such a way that it does not become angry again.

original: evameva kāśyapa yogācāro bhikṣuryatrayatraivaṃ cittasya vikāraṃ paśyati /
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa yoga ācāraḥ bhikṣuḥ yatra yatra evam cittasya vikāram paśyati
translated: In the same way, O Kāśyapa, a meditating monk, wherever he sees a disturbance in the mind,

original: tatra tatraivāsya nigrahāya pratipadyate /
analyzed: tatra tatra eva asya nigrahāya pratipadyate
translated: there, right there, he sets about restraining it.

original: sa tathā tathā cittaṃ nigṛhṇāti yathā na puna prakupyate tatredamucyate / //
analyzed: sa tathā tathā cittam nigṛhṇāti yathā na punar prakupyate tatra idam ucyate
translated: He restrains the mind in such a way that it does not become disturbed again. About this it is said:

original: yathāśvasūta kuśalo bhaveta skhalitaṃ ca aśva samabhigr / hat / /
analyzed: yathā aśvasūta kuśalaḥ bhaveta skhalitam ca
translated: Just as a skilled charioteer controls a horse that has gone astray,

original: yogī tathā cittavikāra dṛṣṭvā tathā nigṛhṇāti yathā na kupyate / //
analyzed: yogī tathā citta vikāra dṛṣṭvā tathā nigṛhṇāti yathā na kupyate
translated: The yogi, seeing the disturbance of the mind, controls it so that it does not become agitated.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa galagraha sarvendriyāṇāṃ graho bhavati jīvitendriyasyoparodhe vartate /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa galagraha sarva indriyāṇām grahaḥ bhavati jīvita indriyasya uparodhe vartate
translated: Just as, O Kāśyapa, a throat disease is a seizure of all the senses and stands in the way of the life faculty,

original: evameva kāśyapa sarvadṛṣṭigatānāmmātmagrāho dharmajīvitendriyasyoparodhena vartate /
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa sarva dṛṣṭi gatānām mā ātma grāhaḥ dharma jīvita indriyasya uparodhena vartate
translated: In the same way, O Kāśyapa, the grasping of a self in all views stands in the way of the life faculty of the Dharma.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: galagraho ve yatha jīvitendriyā nigṛhṇate nāsya sukhaṃ dadāti /
analyzed: jīvita indriyāḥ nigṛhṇate na asya sukham dadāti
translated: Just as a throat disease seizes the life faculty and does not give it any happiness,

original: dṛṣṭikṛtānāmapi ātmadṛṣṭi vināśayeta ima dharmajīvitaṃ //
analyzed: dṛṣṭi kṛtānām api ātma dṛṣṭi vināśayeta dharma jīvitam
translated: The view of a self among the views destroys this life of the Dharma.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa puruṣo yato yataḥ baddho bhavati tatastata eva mocayitavyo bhavati /🔽evameva kāśyapa yato yata eva cittaṃ sajyati /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa puruṣaḥ yatas yatas baddhaḥ bhavati tatas tatas eva mocayitavyaḥ bhavati  evam eva kāśyapa yatas yatas eva cittam sajyati
translated: Just as, O Kāśyapa, a person is to be freed from wherever he is bound,

original: tatastata eva mocayitavyaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: tatas tatas eva mocayitavyam bhavati
translated: In the same way, O Kāśyapa, the mind is to be freed from wherever it is attached.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: yathāpi baddhaḥ puruṣaḥ samantāt samantato mocayitavya bhoti
analyzed: yathā api baddhaḥ puruṣaḥ samantāt samantataḥ
translated: Just as a bound person is to be released from all directions,

original: evaṃ yahīm sajjati mūḍhacittaṃ tatastato yogina mocanīyam //
analyzed: evam sajjati mūḍha cittam tatas tatas yogina mocanīyam
translated: so wherever the deluded mind becomes attached, the yogi is to be released from that.

original: KP / dvāvimau kāśyapa pravrajitasyākāśapaligodhau /
analyzed: dvau imau kāśyapa pravrajitasya ākāśa pali godhau
translated: There are these two clinging to space for a renunciant, Kāśyapa.

original: katamau dvau /
analyzed: katamau dvau
translated: Which two?

original: lokāyatamantraparyeṣṭitā ca /
analyzed: lokāyata mantra paryeṣṭi tā ca
translated: Seeking worldly treatises,

original: utsadapātracīvaradhāraṇatayā ca /
analyzed: utsada pātra cīvara dhāraṇa tayā ca
translated: and being attached to abundant alms bowl and robes.

original: imau dvau /
analyzed: imau dvau
translated: These two.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: lokāyatasyābhyasanābhiyogo tatotsadaṃ cīvarapātradhāraṇaṃ /
analyzed: lokāyatasya abhyasana abhiyogaḥ tata utsadam cīvara pātra dhāraṇam
translated: Devoting oneself to worldly philosophy, and being attached to abundant robes and alms bowl,

original: ākāśabodhe imi dve pratiṣṭhite tau bodhisattvena vivarjanīyau //
analyzed: ākāśa bodhe dve pratiṣṭhite tau bodhisattvena vivarjanīyau
translated: these two are established in clinging to space, they should be avoided by the bodhisattva.

original: KP / dvāvimau kāśyapa pravrajitasya gāḍhabandhano /
analyzed: dvau imau kāśyapa pravrajitasya
translated: There are these two tight bonds for a renunciant, Kāśyapa.

original: katamau dviyadutātmadṛṣṭikṛtabandhanaṃ ca lābhasatkāraślokabandhanaṃ cetīme kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya gāḍhabandhanaṃ /
analyzed: katamau ca lābha satkāra śloka bandhanam ca iti ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya gāḍha bandhanam
translated: Which two? They are: the bond of the view of self, and the bond of gain, honor, and fame. These two, Kāśyapa, are the tight bonds for a renunciant.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: dve bandhane pravrajitasya gāḍhe dṛṣṭikṛtaṃ bandhanam uktam ādaiḥ
analyzed: dve bandhane pravrajitasya gāḍhe dṛṣṭi kṛtam bandhanam uktam
translated: Two tight bonds for a renunciant are said to be the bond of views and the bond of gain,

original: satkāralābho yaśabandhanaṃ ca te sarvadā pravrajitena tyajye //
analyzed: satkāra lābhaḥ yaśa bandhanam ca te sarvadā pravrajitena tyajye
translated: The gain of respect and the bonds of fame should always be abandoned by one who has gone forth.

original: KP / dvāvimau kāśyapa pravrajitasyāntārayakaro dharmau /
analyzed: dvau imau kāśyapa pravrajitasya antāraya karaḥ dharmau
translated: Kāśyapa, there are these two things that obstruct one who has gone forth.

original: katamo dvau /
analyzed: katamaḥ dvau
translated: What are the two?

original: gṛhapatipakṣasevanā ca āryapakṣavidveṣaṇatā cetīme kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasyāntarāyakarau dharmau /
analyzed: gṛhapati pakṣa sevanā ca ārya pakṣa vidveṣaṇa tā ca iti ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya antarāya karau dharmau
translated: Serving the householders' faction and hating the noble faction - these, Kāśyapa, are the two things that obstruct one who has gone forth.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: gṛhasthapakṣasya ca sevanā yā ācāryapakṣasya ca yā vigarhaṇā /
analyzed: gṛhastha pakṣasya ca sevanā yā ācārya pakṣasya ca yā vigarhaṇā
translated: Serving the householders' faction and criticizing the teacher's faction,

original: dvāvantarāyo paripanthabhūto tau bodhisattvena vivaryanīyo //
analyzed: dvau antarāyau paripantha bhūtau tau bodhisattvena vivaryanīyaḥ
translated: These two are obstacles and hindrances, which the bodhisattva should abandon.

original: KP / dvāvimau kāśyapa pravrajitasya malau katamau dvan /
analyzed: dvau imau kāśyapa pravrajitasya malau katamau
translated: Kāśyapa, there are these two stains for one who has gone forth. What are the two?

original: yaduta kleṣādhivāsanatā ca mitrakulabhekṣākakulādvyavasanatāgrahaṇaṃ cetime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya malo /
analyzed: yat uta kleṣa adhivāsana tā ca ca iti ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya
translated: Namely, tolerating afflictions and being attached to the families of friends and alms-giving families - these, Kāśyapa, are the two stains for one who has gone forth.

original: tatredamucyate // //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate  /
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: kleśaśca yo pravrajito dhivāsayet mitraṃ sa bhekṣākakulaṃ ca sevati /
analyzed: kleśaḥ ca yaḥ pravrajitaḥ dhivāsayet mitram sa bhekṣāka kulam ca sevati
translated: The one who has gone forth should not tolerate afflictions, and should not serve the families of friends and alms-giving.

original: etau jinendreṇa hi deśitau malo tau bodhisattvena vivarjanīyoḥ //
analyzed: etau jinendreṇa hi deśitau tau bodhisattvena
translated: These two have been taught by the Lord of Victors as stains, which the bodhisattva should abandon.

original: KP / dvāvimau kāśyapa pravrajitasyāśaniprapātau /
analyzed: dvau imau kāśyapa pravrajitasya aśani prapātau
translated: Kāśyapa, there are these two lightning strikes for a renunciant.

original: katamau dvau /
analyzed: katamau dvau
translated: What are the two?

original: saddharmapratikṣepaśca cyutaśīlasya ca śraddhādeyaparibhogaṃ cetīme kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya aśanīprapāto dharmaḥ tatredamucyate // //
analyzed: saddharma pratikṣepaḥ ca cyuta śīlasya ca śraddhā deya paribhogam ca iti ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya aśanīprapātaḥ dharmaḥ tatra idam ucyate  /
translated: Rejecting the true Dharma and enjoying what is given in faith while one's morality has lapsed - Kāśyapa, these are the two dharmas of lightning strikes for a renunciant. About this, the following is said:

original: saddharmasya pratikṣepa śyutaśīlasya bhojanaṃ /
analyzed: saddharmasya pratikṣepa śyuta śīlasya bhojanam
translated: Rejecting the true Dharma and enjoying what is given in faith while one's morality has lapsed,

original: aśaniprapāto dvāvetau varjanīyo nṛpātmakaiḥ //
analyzed: aśaniprapātaḥ dvau etau varjanīyaḥ nṛpa ātmakaiḥ
translated: these two lightning strikes should be avoided by those who are like kings.

original: KP / dvāvimau kāśyapa pravrajitasya vraṇau katamau dvau /
analyzed: dvau imau kāśyapa pravrajitasya vraṇau katamau dvau
translated: Kāśyapa, there are these two wounds for a renunciant. What are the two?

original: paradau pratyavekṣanatā ca svadauṣapraticchādanatā cetīme kāśyapa dvau pravrajita vraṇau tatredamucyate //
analyzed: para dau pratyavekṣana tā ca sva dauṣa praticchādana tā ca iti ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajita vraṇau tatra idam ucyate
translated: Looking at the faults of others and concealing one's own faults - Kāśyapa, these are the two wounds for a renunciant. About this, the following is said:

original: vṛṇute ca svakā dauṣā paridoṣāśca vīkṣate /
analyzed: vṛṇute ca svakāḥ dauṣā paridoṣāḥ ca vīkṣate
translated: One conceals one's own faults and looks at the faults of others,

original: viṣāgnitulyo dvāvetau vraṇau tyajyau parikṣakaiḥ //
analyzed: viṣa agni tulyaḥ dvau etau vraṇau tyajyau parikṣakaiḥ
translated: these two wounds, like poison and fire, should be abandoned by those who examine.

original: KP / dvāvimau kāśyapa pravrajitasya paridāgho katamo dvau /
analyzed: dvau imau kāśyapa pravrajitasya katamaḥ dvau
translated: Kāśyapa, there are these two fevers for a renunciant. What are the two?

original: yaduta sakāṣāyasya ca kāṣāyadhāraṇaṃ śīlavantā guṇavantā cāntikādupasthānaparicaryāsvīkaraṇaṃ cetīme kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya paridāgho /
analyzed: yat uta sa kāṣāyasya ca kāṣāya dhāraṇam śīlavantā guṇavantā ca antikāt upasthāna paricaryā svīkaraṇam ca iti ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya
translated: Namely, wearing the ochre robes with a defiled mind, and serving and attending upon those endowed with virtue and good qualities. These, Kāśyapa, are the two burnings for one who has gone forth.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: sakaṣāyacittasya kāṣāyadhāraṇaṃ śīlānvitānāṃ ca sakāśa sevanā paricaryupasthānabhivādanaṃ ca dharmāvimau dvau parivarjaṇīyā //
analyzed: sa kaṣāya cittasya kāṣāya dhāraṇam śīla anvitānām ca sakāśaḥ sevanā paricarī upasthāna abhivādanam ca dharmau imau dvau parivarjaṇīyā
translated: Wearing the ochre robes with a defiled mind, and serving and attending upon those endowed with virtue and good qualities, these two dharmas should be abandoned by one who has gone forth.

original: KP / dvāvimau kāśyapa pravrajitasya dīrghaglānyau katamau dvau /
analyzed: dvau imau kāśyapa pravrajitasya dīrgha glānyau katamau dvau
translated: Kāśyapa, these are the two long-lasting sicknesses for one who has gone forth. Which two?

original: yad abhimānikasya ca cittanidhyaptirmahāyānasamprasthitānāṃ sattvānā vicchandanā ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya dīrghagailā /
analyzed: yat abhimānikasya ca citta nidhi aptiḥ mahāyāna samprasthitānām sattvānām vicchandanāḥ ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya
translated: The determination of the mind of one who is conceited, and the discouragement of beings who have set out in the Great Vehicle. These, Kāśyapa, are the two long-lasting sicknesses for one who has gone forth.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: nidhyapti cittasyabhimānikānāṃ vicchandanāyāpi ca buddhayānaṃ /
analyzed: cittasya abhimānikānām ca buddha yānam
translated: The determination of the mind of the conceited, and the discouragement of the Buddha-vehicle,

original: ime hi dve pravrajitasya glānye ukte jinenāpratipudgalena //
analyzed: ime hi dve pravrajitasya glānye ukte jinena apratipudgalena
translated: These two are said to be the sicknesses of one who has gone forth, by the Victor, who is without equal.

original: KP / dvāvimau kāśyapa pravrajitasya acikitso gailānyau /
analyzed: dvau imau kāśyapa pravrajitasya acikitso gailānyau
translated: Kāśyapa, these are the two incurable sicknesses for one who has gone forth.

original: katamau dvau /
analyzed: katamau dvau
translated: Which two?

original: yādutābhīkṣṇāpattiāpadyanatā /
analyzed: yāt uta abhīkṣṇa āpatti āpadi anatā
translated: Being a cheat, and being one who frequently commits offenses.

original: avyutthānatā ceti ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya acikitso glānyo //
analyzed: a vyutthāna tā ca iti ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya
translated: Not recovering, and not getting better. These, Kāśyapa, are the two incurable sicknesses of a renunciant.

original: KP / dvāvimau kāśyapa pravrajitasya śalyo katamau dvau /
analyzed: dvau imau kāśyapa pravrajitasya śalyo katamau dvau
translated: Kāśyapa, these two are the barbs of a renunciant. Which two?

original: yaduta śikṣāpadasamatikramaṃ ca anādattasārasya ca kālakriyā ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya śalyo //
analyzed: yat uta śikṣā pada samatikramam ca an ādatta sārasya ca kālakriyāḥ ime kāśyapa dvau pravrajitasya śalyaḥ
translated: Exceeding the precepts, and dying without having attained the essence. These, Kāśyapa, are the two barbs of a renunciant.

original: KP / śramaṇa śramaṇa iti kāśyapa ucyate /
analyzed: śramaṇa śramaṇaḥ iti kāśyapaḥ ucyate
translated: Kāśyapa, one is called an ascetic, an ascetic.

original: kiyannu tāvat kāśyapa śramaṇaḥ śramaṇa ityucyate /🔽catvāra ime kāśyapa śramaṇaḥ katame catvāraḥ yaduta varṇarūpaliṅgasaṃsthānaśramaṇa /
analyzed: kiyat nu tāvat kāśyapa śramaṇaḥ śramaṇaḥ iti ucyate  catvāraḥ ime kāśyapa śramaṇaḥ katame catvāraḥ yat uta varṇa rūpa liṅga saṃsthāna śramaṇa
translated: Kāśyapa, how many are called an ascetic, an ascetic?🔽Kāśyapa, there are four ascetics. Which four?

original: ācāraguptikuhakaśramaṇaḥ kīrtiśabdaślokaśramaṇaḥ bhūtapratipattiśramaṇaḥ ime kāśyapa catvāraḥ śramaṇāḥ /
analyzed: ācāra gupti kuhaka śramaṇaḥ kīrti śabda śloka śramaṇaḥ bhūta pratipatti śramaṇaḥ ime kāśyapa catvāraḥ śramaṇāḥ
translated: Namely, the ascetic who has the color, form, mark, and appearance, the ascetic who is deceitful in conduct and hypocrisy, the ascetic who is famous, renowned, and has a good reputation, and the ascetic who has realized the truth. These, Kāśyapa, are the four ascetics.

original: KP / tatra kāśyapa katamo varṇarūpaliṅgasaṃsthānaśramaṇaḥ iha kāśyapa ihekatyaśramaṇa varaṇarupaliṅgasaṃsthānasamanvāgato bhavati /
analyzed: tatra kāśyapa katamaḥ varṇa rūpa liṅga saṃsthāna śramaṇaḥ iha kāśyapa iha ikatya śramaṇa varaṇa rupa liṅga saṃsthāna samanvāgataḥ bhavati
translated: Among them, Kāśyapa, what is the ascetic who has the color, form, mark, and appearance? Here, Kāśyapa, some ascetic is endowed with the color, form, mark, and appearance.

original: saṅghāṭīpariveṣṭhito muṇḍaśiraḥ supātrapāṇaiḥ parigṛhītaḥ sa ca bhavatyapariśuddhakāyakarmasamudācāra apariśuddhavākkarmasamudācāraḥ apariśuddhamanaskarmasamudācārauḥ 🔽bhavati /
analyzed: saṅghāṭī pariveṣṭhitaḥ muṇḍa śiraḥ supātra pāṇaiḥ parigṛhītaḥ sa ca bhavati a pariśuddha kāya karma samudācāra a pariśuddha vāc karma samudācāraḥ a pariśuddha manaḥ karma samudācārauḥ  bhavati
translated: He is surrounded by a patched robe, has a shaven head, and holds a good alms bowl in his hand. And he has impure bodily conduct, impure verbal conduct, and impure mental conduct.

original: ayukta amuktaḥ adāntaḥ aśāntaḥ aguptaḥ avinitaḥ lubdhaḥ alasoḥ duḥśīlappāpadharmasamācāraḥ ayamucyate kāśyapa varṇarūpaliṅgasaṃsthānaśramaṇaḥ
analyzed: a yukta a muktaḥ a dāntaḥ a śāntaḥ a guptaḥ lubdhaḥ a lasoḥ duḥśīla ppāpa dharma samācāraḥ ayam ucyate kāśyapa varṇa rūpa liṅga saṃsthāna śramaṇaḥ
translated: He is not restrained, not liberated, not tamed, not peaceful, not guarded, not disciplined, greedy, lazy, and practices bad conduct and bad qualities. This, Kāśyapa, is called the monk who has the form, appearance, and figure of a monk.

original: KP / tatra kāśyapa katamaḥ ācāraguptikuhakaḥ śramaṇaḥ iha kāśyapa ihaikatyaśramaṇaḥ
analyzed: tatra kāśyapa katamaḥ ācāra gupti kuhakaḥ śramaṇaḥ iha kāśyapa iha ekatya śramaṇaḥ
translated: Therein, Kāśyapa, what is the monk who is a hypocrite who hides his conduct? Here, Kāśyapa, some monk

original: ācāracāritrasampano bhavati samprajānacārī caturbhi īryāpathairlūhānnapānabhojī santuṣṭaḥ
analyzed: ācāra cāritra sampanaḥ bhavati samprajāna cārī caturbhiḥ īryāpathaiḥ lūha anna pāna bhojī santuṣṭaḥ
translated: is endowed with good conduct and behavior, and is aware in the four postures. He eats coarse food and drink, and is content.

original: caturbhirāryavaṃśerasaṃsṛṣṭo gṛhasthapravrajitairalpabhāṣyo 'lpamantraḥ te cāsyeryāpathāḥ
analyzed: caturbhiḥ ārya vaṃśeḥ asaṃsṛṣṭaḥ gṛhastha pravrajitaiḥ alpa bhāṣyaḥ lpa mantraḥ te ca asya īryāpathāḥ
translated: He is not mixed with householders and renunciants through the four noble lineages. He speaks little and has few affairs. And his postures

original: kuhanalapanatayā kalpitā bhavanti /
analyzed: kuhana lapana tayā kalpitāḥ bhavanti
translated: are contrived through hypocrisy and flattery.

original: na cittapariśuddhaye /
analyzed: na citta pariśuddhaye
translated: Not for the purification of the mind.

original: na śamāya nopaśamāya /
analyzed: na śamāya na upaśamāya
translated: Not for peace, not for tranquility,

original: na damāya /
analyzed: na damāya
translated: not for self-control,

original: upalambhadṛṣṭikaśca bhavati /
analyzed: upalambha dṛṣṭikaḥ ca bhavati
translated: And he has the view of grasping.

original: śūnyatānupalambhāśca dharmesu śrutvā prapātasañjñī bhavati /
analyzed: śūnyatā anupalambhāḥ ca dharmesu śrutvā prapāta sañjñī bhavati
translated: And having heard about the non-apprehension of emptiness in phenomena, he has the notion of a precipice.

original: śūnyatāvādināṃ ca bhikṣuṇām antike aprasādasañjñim utpādayati iyam ucyate kāśyapa ācāraguptikuhaka śramaṇaḥ //
analyzed: śūnyatā vādinām ca bhikṣuṇām antike aprasāda sañjñim utpādayati iyam ucyate kāśyapaḥ ācāra gupti kuhaka śramaṇaḥ
translated: And he arouses the notion of lack of faith towards monks who proclaim emptiness. This, Kāśyapa, is called the monk who is a hypocrite, a deceiver, a flatterer.

original: KP / tatra kāśyapa katamaḥ kīrtiśabdaślokaḥ śramaṇaḥ iha kāśyapa ihaikatyaśramaṇaḥ pratisaṅkhyāya śīlaṃ rakṣati /
analyzed: tatra kāśyapa katamaḥ kīrti śabda ślokaḥ śramaṇaḥ iha kāśyapaḥ iha ekatya śramaṇaḥ pratisaṅkhyāya śīlam rakṣati
translated: Now, Kāśyapa, what is the monk who seeks fame, reputation, and praise? Here, Kāśyapa, some monk observes morality with deliberation.

original: kathamān pare jānīyurśīlavatān iti /
analyzed: kathamān pare jānīyuḥ śīlavatān iti
translated: How can others know me as one who has morality?

original: pratisaṅkhyāya śrutam udgṛhṇīte kathamāṃ pare jānīyurbahuśruta iti /
analyzed: pratisaṅkhyāya śrutam udgṛhṇīte kathamām pare jānīyuḥ bahu śrutaḥ iti
translated: With deliberation he memorizes what he has heard. How can others know me as one who has much learning?

original: pratisaṅkhyāyāraṇye prativasati /
analyzed: pratisaṅkhyāya araṇye prativasati
translated: With deliberation he dwells in the forest.

original: kathamāṃ pare jānīyu āraṇyaka iti /
analyzed: kathamām pare jānīyu āraṇyakaḥ iti
translated: How can others know me as one who dwells in the forest?

original: pratisaṅkhyāya alpecchaḥ santuṣṭaḥ pravivikto viharat /
analyzed: pratisaṅkhyāya alpa icchaḥ santuṣṭaḥ praviviktaḥ viharat
translated: With deliberation he is content with few desires, and dwells in solitude.

original: yāvad eva paropadarśanāya na nirvedāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya nopaśamāya /
analyzed: yāvat eva para upadarśanāya na nirvedāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upaśamāya
translated: Only in order to show others, not for disenchantment, not for dispassion, not for cessation, not for peace,

original: nā sambodhaye /
analyzed: nā sambodhaye
translated: not for higher knowledge,

original: na śrāmaṇyāya /
analyzed: na śrāmaṇyāya
translated: not for the life of an ascetic,

original: na brāhmaṇāya /
analyzed: na brāhmaṇāya
translated: not for the life of a brahmin,

original: na nirvāṇāya /
analyzed: na nirvāṇāya
translated: not for nirvana.

original: ayamucyate kāśyapa kīrtiśabdaślokaśramaṇa //
analyzed: ayam ucyate kāśyapa kīrti śabda śloka śramaṇa
translated: Kāśyapa, this is called the monk who is lazy about fame, reputation, and praise.

original: KP / tatra kāśyapa katamo bhūtapratipattiḥ śramaṇaḥ yaḥ kāśyapa bhikṣuranarthiko bhavati kāyena ca jīvitenāpi /
analyzed: tatra kāśyapa katamaḥ bhūta pratipattiḥ śramaṇaḥ yaḥ kāśyapa bhikṣuḥ anarthikaḥ bhavati kāyena ca jīvitena api
translated: Kāśyapa, what is the monk who has correct practice? Kāśyapa, it is the monk who is disinterested in the body and even in life,

original: kaḥ punarvvādo lābhasatkāraśloke /
analyzed: kaḥ punar vvādaḥ lābha satkāra śloke
translated: let alone gain, honor, and fame.

original: śūnyatā ānimittā apraṇihitāśca dhrmāṃ śrutvā āptamano bhavati tathatvatāyāṃ pratipanno nirvāṇe cāpyanarthikā brahmacaryaṃ carati /
analyzed: śūnyatāḥ ānimittāḥ apraṇihitāḥ ca dhrmām śrutvā āpta manaḥ bhavati tathatva tāyām pratipannaḥ nirvāṇe ca api anarthikāḥ brahmacaryam carati
translated: Having heard about emptiness, signlessness, and wishlessness, he becomes pleased and enters into reality. He even has no interest in nirvāṇa, and practices celibacy.

original: kaḥ punarvādastraidhātukābhinandanatayā śūnyatādṛṣṭyāpyanarthiko bhavati /
analyzed: kaḥ punar vādaḥ traidhātuka abhinandana tayā śūnyatā dṛṣṭyā api anarthikaḥ bhavati
translated: Let alone being disinterested in the view of emptiness, he even has no interest in delighting in the three realms.

original: kaḥ punarvāda ātmasattvajīvapauṣapudgaladṛṣṭyā /
analyzed: kaḥ punar vādaḥ ātma sattva jīva pauṣa pudgala dṛṣṭyā
translated: Let alone the view of self, sentient being, life, person, or pudgala.

original: dharmapratisaraṇaśca bhavati /
analyzed: dharma pratisaraṇaḥ ca bhavati
translated: He takes refuge in the Dharma.

original: kleṣānāṃ ca adhyātmavimokṣamargati /
analyzed: kleṣānām ca adhyātma vimokṣam argati
translated: He seeks the path of liberation within,

original: na bahirdhā dhāvati atyantapariśuddhāśca prakṛtyā sarvadharmā asaṅkliṣṭān paśyati /
analyzed: na bahirdhā dhāvati atyanta pariśuddhāḥ ca prakṛtyā sarva dharmāḥ asaṅkliṣṭān paśyati
translated: and does not run outside. He sees that all phenomena are extremely pure by nature and uncontaminated.

original: ātmadvīpaśca bhavatyananyadvīpaḥ dharmato 'pi tathāgataṃ na samanupaśyati kaḥ punarvāda rūpakāyena /
analyzed: ātma dvīpaḥ ca bhavati an anya dvīpaḥ tathāgatam na samanupaśyati kaḥ punar vāda rūpa kāyena
translated: He is an island unto himself, not relying on others. He does not even see the Tathāgata as the Dharma, let alone the rūpakāya.

original: virāgato 'pi dharmaṃ nābhiniviśate kaḥ punarvāda uta vākpathodāharaṇena /
analyzed: virāgataḥ pi dharmam na abhiniviśate kaḥ punar vādaḥ uta vākpatha udāharaṇena
translated: One who is free from passion does not even conceive of the Dharma, let alone give an example with words.

original: asaṃskṛtamapi cāryasaṅghaṃ na vikalpayati /
analyzed: a saṃskṛtam api ca ārya saṅgham na vikalpayati
translated: And one does not conceptualize even the Unsurpassed Assembly.

original: kaḥ punarvādo gaṇasaṃ nipātataḥ nāpi kasyaciddharmasya prarhāṇāyābhiyukto bhavati na bhāvanāyairna sākṣīkriyāya /
analyzed: kaḥ punar vādaḥ nipātataḥ na api kasyacid dharmasya prarhāṇāya abhiyuktaḥ bhavati na sākṣīkriyāya
translated: And one is not devoted to the abandonment of any dharma, nor to its cultivation, nor to its realization.

original: na saṃsāre virohati /🔽na nirvāṇam abhinandati /
analyzed: na saṃsāre virohati  na nirvāṇam abhinandati
translated: One does not grow in saṃsāra.🔽One does not delight in nirvāṇa.

original: na mokṣaṃ paryeṣate /
analyzed: na mokṣam paryeṣate
translated: One does not seek liberation.

original: na bandhaṃ /
analyzed: na bandham
translated: Nor bondage.

original: prakṛtiparinirvṛtā ca sarvadharmān viditvā na saṃsarati na pariṇirvāyati /
analyzed: prakṛti parinirvṛtā ca sarva dharmān viditvā na saṃsarati na pariṇirvāyati
translated: And having known all dharmas to be naturally completely extinguished, one does not transmigrate, nor does one completely extinguish [anything].

original: ayamucyate kāśyapa bhūtapratipattiḥ śramaṇaḥ //
analyzed: ayam ucyate kāśyapa bhūta pratipattiḥ śramaṇaḥ
translated: This, Kāśyapa, is called the true practice of an ascetic.

original: bhūtapratipattyā śrāmaṇyāyogaḥ karaṇīya na nāmahetena bhavitavyo ime kāśyapa catvāra śramaṇā /
analyzed: bhūta pratipattyā śrāmaṇyā yogaḥ karaṇīya na nāma hetena ime kāśyapa catvāra
translated: The practice of asceticism should be done with true practice, one should not be one who merely has the name. These, Kāśyapa, are the four kinds of ascetics.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, the following is said:

original: KP / yo kāyavākcittamaneraśuddho adāntagupto avinīta lubdho
analyzed: kāya vāc citta maneḥ aśuddhaḥ a dānta guptaḥ
translated: He who is impure in body, speech, mind, and thought, who is undisciplined, unguarded, untrained, and greedy,

original: muṇḍaḥśiraścīvarapātrapāṇī saṃsthānaliṅgā śramaṇeṣu vukto
analyzed: saṃsthāna liṅgā śramaṇeṣu
translated: With a shaven head, wearing robes and carrying a bowl, is said to have the form and appearance of an ascetic,

original: ācāracaryāpsamanvito 'pi rūkṣānnabhojī kuhanādisevī
analyzed: rūkṣa anna bhojī kuhanā ādi sevī
translated: Even if endowed with conduct and practice, eating coarse food, serving with flattery and so on,

original: caturāryavaṃśehi samanvito 'pi saṃsarga durāt parivarjayanto
analyzed: catur ārya vaṃśehi samanvitaḥ pi saṃsarga durāt parivarjayantaḥ
translated: Even if endowed with the four noble lineages, avoiding association with the wicked,

original: te cāsya sarve na damāya bhonti na śāntaye nāpi ca nirvidāya /
analyzed: te ca asya sarve na damāya bhonti na śāntaye na api ca nirvidāya
translated: All of these do not lead to his restraint, nor to peace, nor to disenchantment.

original: śūnyānimitteṣu prapātasañjñī ācāraguptiḥ kuhako dvitīyoḥ
analyzed: śūnya animitteṣu prapāta sañjñī ācāra guptiḥ kuhakaḥ
translated: The second is one who hides his conduct and is deceitful, perceiving a precipice in emptiness and signlessness.

original: dhutā guṇā śīla śrutaṃ samādhiḥ parasya visvāpanahetu kurvati /
analyzed: samādhiḥ parasya visvāpana hetu kurvati
translated: The ascetic qualities, morality, learning, and concentration, he makes the cause for others' sleep.

original: na śāntaye nāpi ca nirvidāya kīrtīyaślokaśramaṇostṛtīya /
analyzed: na śāntaye na api ca nirvidāya
translated: Not for peace, nor for disenchantment, the third is the monk who strives for fame and praise.

original: kāyena yo arthika jīvitena vā yo lābhasatkāraparāmukhaśca
analyzed: jīvitena vā yaḥ lābha satkāra parāmukhaḥ ca
translated: One who is devoted to the body and life, and who turns away from gain and honor,

original: vimokṣa utpādamukhaṃ ca śrutvā anarthikā sarvabhavadgatīṣu / //
analyzed: vimokṣe utpāda mukham ca śrutvā anarthikā sarva bhavat gatīṣu
translated: Having heard the door to liberation and the path of production, not desiring any existence or destiny,

original: atyantaśūnyāśca parīkṣa dharmān na nirvṛtiṃ paśyati nāpyanirvṛtiṃ /
analyzed: atyanta śūnyāḥ ca parīkṣa dharmān na nirvṛtim paśyati na api anirvṛtim
translated: Examining the dharmas as utterly empty, he does not see nirvana or non-nirvana.

original: virāgato dharmamavekṣate sadā asaṃskṛtaṃ dharmam anitya nirvṛtaḥ //
analyzed: virāgataḥ dharmam avekṣate sadā asaṃskṛtam dharmam anitya nirvṛtaḥ
translated: Always observing the Dharma through dispassion, the unconditioned Dharma is eternally liberated.

original: KP / tadythāpi nāma kāśyapa daridrapuruṣasya samṛdhakośa iti nāmadheyamaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa daridra puruṣasya samṛdha kośaḥ iti nāmadheyamam bhavet
translated: Thus have I heard: Once the Buddha was dwelling in the Jeta Grove of Anathapindika's Park near Shravasti, together with a great assembly of 1,250 bhikshus.🔽At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhikshus: 'Bhikshus, you should know that there are two kinds of people who are difficult to satisfy and difficult to serve. What are the two? They are the king and the arhat.

original: tatkiṃ manyase kāśyapa anurūpaṃ tasya daridrapuruṣasya tannāmadheyaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: tat kim manyase kāśyapa anurūpam tasya daridra puruṣasya tat nāmadheyam bhavet
translated: What do you think, Kāśyapa, would that name befit that poor man?

original: āha no hīdam bhadanta bhagavan /
analyzed: āha no hi idam bhadanta bhagavan
translated: He said, No indeed, Blessed One.

original: bhagavān āha /
analyzed: bhagavān āha
translated: The Blessed One said:

original: evameva kāśyapa ye te śramaṇabrāhmaṇa ityucyante /
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa ye te śramaṇa brāhmaṇaḥ iti ucyante
translated: Just so, Kāśyapa, those who are called ascetics and brahmins,

original: na ca śramaṇabrāhmaṇasamanvāgatā bhavanti /
analyzed: na ca śramaṇa brāhmaṇa samanvāgatāḥ bhavanti
translated: but are not endowed with the qualities of ascetics and brahmins,

original: tān ahaṃ daridiapuruṣān iti vadāmi /
analyzed: tān aham daridia puruṣān iti vadāmi
translated: I say they are poor men.

original: tatredamucyate
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: yathā daridrasya bhaveta nāmaṃ samṛddhakośambhi na tacca śobhate /
analyzed: yathā daridrasya bhaveta nāmam samṛddha kośambhi na tat ca śobhate
translated: Just as the name of a poor man would not befit one with a prosperous treasury,

original: śrāmaṇyahīna śramaṇo na śobhate daridra āḍhyetiva ucyamānaḥ //
analyzed: śrāmaṇya hīna śramaṇaḥ na śobhate daridraḥ ucyamānaḥ
translated: A monk devoid of monkhood does not shine, being called 'rich' while poor.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa kaścideva puruṣo mahatā udakārṇavenohyamānaḥ tṛṣayā kālaṃ kuryāt /
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa kaścid eva puruṣaḥ mahatā udakārṇavena uhyamānaḥ tṛṣayā kālam kuryāt
translated: For example, Kāśyapa, suppose a man, being carried away by a great flood of water, were to die of thirst.

original: evameva kāśyapa ihekatye śramaṇabrāhmaṇo bahun dharmān paryāpnuvanti na rāgatṛṣṇān vinodayanti /
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa iha ikatye śramaṇa brāhmaṇaḥ bahun dharmān paryāpnuvanti na rāga tṛṣṇān vinodayanti
translated: In the same way, Kāśyapa, here some ascetics and brahmins study many teachings, but do not dispel the craving for desire,

original: na dveṣatṛṣṇā na mohatṛṣṇā śaknuvanti vinodayituṃ /
analyzed: na dveṣa tṛṣṇā na moha tṛṣṇā śaknuvanti vinodayitum
translated: nor are they able to dispel the craving for hatred or the craving for delusion.

original: te mahatā dharmārṇavenohyamānā kleśatṛṣāyā kālagatā durgatigāmino bhavanti /
analyzed: te mahatā dharma arṇavena uhyamānā kleśa tṛṣāyā kālagatāḥ durgati gāminaḥ bhavanti
translated: Being carried away by the great river of the Dharma, they die of thirst for the afflictions and go to the lower realms.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: yathā manuṣyo udakārṇavena uhyanti tṛṣṇāya kareya kālam /
analyzed: yathā manuṣyaḥ udakārṇavena uhyanti tṛṣṇāya kareya kālam
translated: Just as a person is carried away by the river of water and dies of thirst,

original: tathā paṭhantā bahudharmatṛṣṇayā dharmārṇavasthāmi vrajantyapāyaṃ //
analyzed: tathā paṭhantā bahu dharma tṛṣṇayā dharma arṇava sthāmi vrajantī apāyam
translated: In the same way, those who study out of craving for the Dharma go to the lower realms while standing in the river of the Dharma.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa vaidyo oṣadhabhāraṃ gṛhītvā anuvicaret tasya kaścid eva vyādhi utpadyeta na ca taṃ vyādhi śaknuyācikitsituṃ
analyzed: tat yathā api nāma kāśyapa vaidyaḥ oṣadha bhāram gṛhītvā anuvicaret tasya kaścid eva vyādhi utpadyeta na ca tam vyādhi śaknuyāt cikitsitum
translated: For example, Kashyapa, a doctor might go around carrying a load of medicine, but if he himself were to become ill and unable to cure that illness,

original: evameva kāśyapa bahuśrutasya kleśavyādhi draṣṭavyā yastena śrutena na śaknoti ātmanaḥ kleṣavyādhi cikitsituṃ /
analyzed: evam eva kāśyapa bahu śrutasya kleśa vyādhi draṣṭavyāḥ yaḥ tena śrutena na śaknoti ātmanaḥ kleṣa vyādhi cikitsitum
translated: in the same way, Kashyapa, the illness of the afflictions of the one with much learning should be seen. If he is unable to cure the illness of his own afflictions with that learning,

original: nirarthakaṃ tasya tacchrutaṃ bhaviṣyati /
analyzed: nirarthakam tasya tat śrutam bhaviṣyati
translated: that learning will be meaningless for him.

original: tatredamucyate //
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding this, it is said:

original: yatheva vaidyauṣadharbharastrasaṃsthe parilhrameta nikhilaṃhi loke /
analyzed: yathā iva vaidya auṣadha rastra saṃsthe parilhrameta nikhilam hi loke
translated: Just as a doctor, full of all medicines, would be unable to cure the illnesses that arise in the world,

original: utpannavyādhīn a nivartayeca nirarthakaṃ tasya bhaveta taṃ hi /
analyzed: utpanna vyādhīn nivartayet ca nirarthakam tasya bhaveta tam hi
translated: that would be meaningless for him.

original: bhikṣustathā śīlaguṇerupetaḥ śrutena yukto 'pi na ca ścikitset /
analyzed: bhikṣuḥ tathā śīla guṇeḥ upetaḥ śrutena yuktaḥ na ca ścikitset
translated: A monk who is endowed with morality and good qualities, but who is not trained in learning,

original: ayoniśa kleśasamutthitā rujā vṛthā śramastasya śrutābhiyogaḥ //
analyzed: kleśa samutthitāḥ rujāḥ vṛthā śramaḥ tasya śruta abhiyogaḥ
translated: His exertion in learning is in vain, as it does not cure the illness arisen from improper mental afflictions.

original: KP / tadyathāpi nāma kāśyapa /
